abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the China Second
            National Highway Project are as follows: Project outcome is
            satisfactory; sustainability is likely; institutional
            development impact is substantial; Bank performance is
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            Several lessons were gleaned from this project including: 1)
            The experience of this project is that preparation of a
            bi-provincial highway project consumes about the same
            resources (in terms of staff weeks and budget) as two
            separate one-province highway projects. Coordination between
            Guangdong and Hunan was complicated because Hunan was a
            first time Bank highway borrower, while for Guangdong it was
            the second experience. Better information exchanges between
            provinces could have accelerated the Hunan procurement of
            electrical and mechanical equipment. 2) With hindsight, the
            project was approved with insufficient attention paid to
            surveys and design. 3) While improvements in overweight
            enforcement will limit the degree of overloading, there are
            additional measures that should in the future be implemented
            at the design stage to improve the safety of new roads.
            Working with the Ministry of Communications to update design
            standards, improving training of designers, and implementing
            proper design safety audits would significantly improve the
            safety situation on similar projects. 4) There was pressure
            to complete work, which led to the project specifying very
            tight schedules in its contracts, often necessitating
            extensions. It also affected quality. It is important to
            adopt sensible schedules for construction, especially when
            the terrain is complex. 5) Lastly, it is necessary to
            carefully review the class and designs of the
            interconnecting roads to ensure that they are sufficient to
            meet the likely traffic demand from the expressway.

abstracts.cdata!:
The specific objectives of the Second
            National Highway Project are to: a) relieve road transport
            congestion and improve the integration of interregional
            trade and commerce; b) strengthen institutional capacity; c)
            develop a policy dialogue in the areas of the
            commercialization and corporatization of provincial
            expressway companies, highway maintenance management and
            transport and economic integration; and d) improve the
            safety of road transport.  The project comprises the
            following components: a) expressway construction, including
            service and maintenance facilities and toll plazas; b)
            interconnecting roads programs; c) highway construction; d)
            construction supervision services; e) studies in highway
            maintenance management, expressway commercialization and
            corporatization, economic integration, and expressway
            safety; f) staff training programs; and g) equipment.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Second National Highway Project :
            environmental assessment summary

abstracts.cdata!:
This report presents an environmental
            assessment of the Second National Highway Project of China.
            The section under environmental impact analysis is a
            four-lane, 169km total access controlled expressway linking
            the towns of Xiangtan and Leiyang, which is to be
            constructed between 1996 and 1999.  The three phases of
            project implementation are design, construction, and
            operation.  For each of these phases the potential impacts
            on the environment have been examined, with special
            consideration paid to the areas of ecological protection,
            soil erosion, leakage of hazardous materials, flood control,
            maintenance of drainage systems, waste management, vehicle
            management, land occupation, resettlement of occupants,
            cultural relic preservation, and noise, water and
            atmospheric pollution.  Mitigation measures have been
            developed to prevent and combat potential adverse
            environmental effects of the project.  These are included in
            plans of environmental management, supervision, monitoring,
            and action, which will require the participation of both the
            government and the public.  It has been concluded by this
            environmental assessment that the environment will suffer no
            serious consequences as a result of the project.  It states
            that all adverse impacts can be mitigated or eliminated by
            implementing the environmental protection measures.

docna.cdata!:
China - Second National Highway Project :
            environmental assessment summary

China - Second National Highway
